name: disadvantageously
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
in a way that causes problems, especially causing something or someone to be less successful than other things or people: Such changes can disadvantageously interfere with the data management. Litigants should not be treated disadvantageously in deciding costs simply because they are wealthy.
More examplesFewer examplesShe was afraid of making herself disadvantageously conspicuous.The study emphasizes some of the ways in which the state disadvantageously differentiates women from men.They find themselves placed in a disadvantageously unfair position to cope with the situation.
